titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Rose by Candle light and took a long walk before breakfast— Walked again before dinner— I intended to have written two or three hours; but the days are now so short that unless the precise moment is seized they are gone— My walks and Charles’s lessons took up all the hours of day-light, and my writing was postponed untill to-morrow. We had a visit in the Evening from Mr Proud, and Mr Plummer—they had intelligence from America to 3. October— Nothing important— Charles became sufficiently Master of the first lesson of St: Quentin’s Grammar— The Ladies were to have gone to the Theatre, at which a French Opera had been announced— It was changed however for a Russian play— Great efforts have been made to obtain the dismissal of all the French players, and it has been repeatedly said that the Emperor had determined to dismiss them— The Russian public have manifested some uneasiness at their continuance here, and every thing french, even the language has become an object of their abhorrence.

2. I omitted my walk before breakfast for the sake of having time to write; but I walked before dinner— Dr: Galloway came and sat half an hour with me; conversing upon subjects of Natural History and Philosophy.— Cards in the Evening after tea— The rest of the day I was engaged with Charles.

3. This forenoon I called at Mr: Raimbert’s, in order to settle an account with Mr Montreal, but neither of them was at home. I then paid a visit at Mr Dimond’s lodgings, but he was absent from them— Captain Guedes I found— He has been confined three weeks to his chamber, and part of the time to his bed, with a nervous fever, which has exceedingly reduced him, but from which he is now convalescent— He had some English Newspapers, which he sent me in the Evening. I dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a Company of about forty persons; among whom were the Ladies of the celebrated Generals, who are now dispelling as Count Litta remarked, like a fog before the Sun, the immense armies of the Emperor Napoleon, and levelling with the dust his Colossal Military Reputation— Princess Kutuzoff—Smolenski—Countess Wittgenstein, Baronesses Benigsen, and Winzingerode, and several others. The day was rendered peculiarly joyous to them, by the news of a fresh
splendid victory over the Corps of the French Marshals Victor and Oudinot, by Count Wittgenstein, which arrived this morning. Within the compass of ten days the Russian armies have taken between forty and fifty-thousand prisoners—with Cannon, baggage and ammunition in proportion— There is nothing like it in History since the days of Xerxes— I sat at table next to Admiral Kutuzoff, a nephew of the Prince of Smolensk; le vainqueur du vainqueur de la Terre; who entered into conversation with me, and told me some anecdotes of his uncle; who he says is as good as he is great. He has been more than fifty years in the service—employed in important military and diplomatic stations, successively by the Empress Catherine, and the Emperors Paul and Alexander.— He said that just before the Prince went away on this last appointment, he the Admiral was enumerating the multitude of military commands and important embassies, upon which he had been for so long a series employed; when the old Prince, with a grave countenance told him that he had forgotten one of his high Offices— what was that?— Director of the German Theatre— It was remarkable, the Admiral observed, that Napoleon’s present disasters were owing to his having despised his enemy, and Prince Kutuzoff’s success, might be due to the opposite cause—for he was an enthusiastic admirer of Napoleon’s military genius, and on going away last Summer told him, that when he considered whom he was going to oppose, he felt overpowered by the magnitude of the responsibility he was taking upon himself— And he had lately written him, that notwithstanding he had now the pleasure of beating day after day, the first Captain of the Age; and notwithstanding the honours that were heaping upon him, he longed for the time when he could return here, to his friends.— The Admiral told me that there had been here an English Admiral named Bentinck, a vain glorious bragging sort of man, and he and Madame de Stael one day said to him that Prince Kutuzoff was destined to be a second Wellington— But they were much mistaken in supposing he should take it as a Compliment— If his uncle had done nothing more than Wellington; he would sink low indeed from the summit of his merited fame— I said that the English, were apt to make much of small successes by land; but I thought they might be allowed a little pride upon the Battle of Salamanca— Thanks, said he to the random shot that carried away Marmont’s arm, just before the battle began— But here is Wellington, with his whole Army stop’d for weeks before a paltry little fort at Burgos, with a garrison of 2000 men, which he cannot take— And if it were not for our Victories in the North I would lay a wager the French would be now again in Madrid— The Admiral was equally severe in his remarks upon the Spaniards, and was peculiarly sarcastic upon Mr Zea, who sat opposite to us at table— He first asked me who he was— I said Mr Zea, the Spanish Minister— Spanish Minister? what?—Joseph Bonaparte’s— “No—Ferdinand the Seventh’s— The Minister of the Cortes; who had signed a Treaty with Count Romanzoff—” “Oh! Yes! the Garçon de Comtoir of Colombi, the merchant— Why, what a Diplomatic tone he assumes!— You smile I see— But I am no diplomatic man. I say just what comes into my head[”]— I said that Mr Zea had been connected with the House of Colombi; but that I believed he had been a diplomatic character sub rosa, even then; as Mr Colombi himself had been while he lived.— That his widow had since his death been made a Countess by the regency, for his services— Upon all which the Admiral spoke with as little respect for Ferdinand 7. and the Cortes, as he had of the English and of Lord Wellington. I told him that I had witnessed, with interest and admiration the Spirit manifested by all Classes of people, in this Nation; under the struggle, from which they are issuing with such triumphant glory— That I had never entertained a low idea, of Russia; but that the conduct of the Nation upon this severe trial, had far exceeded my expectations— He said, Monsieur—La Russie, bien gouvernée, est faite pour commander à l’Europe—I think she will not lose the opportunity— I observed however that the circumstance which appeared most to gratify the Admiral in speaking of the conduct of the Nation, was that the peasants had not shewn the least disposition to avail themselves of the occasion to obtain their freedom— I see that this is what most touches the feelings of all the Russians with whom I have conversed on this subject— This was the point upon which their fears were the greatest, and that upon which they are most delighted to see the danger past— The Admiral, whose name I did not know untill upon enquiry after dinner I ascertained it, professed to be so pleased with my remarks, that he told me he hoped to have the opportunity of introducing me personally to his uncle when he should come home— Count Romanzoff told me that he had sent the last letter I wrote him to the Emperor, who had been well pleased with it.— I asked him if he had received any answer from England, on the proposal of Mediation— He said it had not been rejected, but they had intimated an opinion, that it would not be acceptable to the American Government— That they expected something might be done after the new Election in America; by which the Count said he understood them to mean that Mr Madison after being re-elected would be more pacifically inclined than he is at present— I said the English Government were much misinformed concerning American Affairs— I believed the Emperor’s
proposal would be very acceptable, whatever the Event of our election might be.— Lord Cathcart also said to me that the Elections for the new Parliament in England were now over; but said he they are more anxious there I believe about your Elections than about our own— I said that our Election was of a different description from their’s; it being not only of members of the Legislature but also of the head of the Executive Department— He said he was glad to observe that there did not appear to have been any thing to excite rancour on either side— I told him, from the complexion of the Newspapers, I thought there was more of that in England than in America— I came home early, and employed the Evening with Charles.

4. At length I received this day, from Mr Monroe, Secretary of State, a letter, dated 1. July last announcing the Declaration of War, against Great-Britain, and enclosing the President’s Message to Congress, the Report of the Committee recommending the Declaration, and the President’s Proclamation founded upon it. I also received from Mr J. L. Harris a letter, dated Stockholm 18 November.— Mr Harris the Consul spent part of the Evening with us— He has some apprehensions of the ill-effects of English influence here at the present time; and is much mortified, at the airs and tone which the English here assume at this moment of boundless exultation over their most dreaded enemy— That there is danger cannot be denied; but I think their indiscretions will operate more against them than in their favour.— Charles was sent to dine at Madame Colombi’s, and was consequently indisposed for his ordinary evening’s amusement— Mr Montreal was here this morning, and I finally settled with him on account of Mr Smith— His situation and that of his relations here is painful and uncomfortable— They appear to think it not without danger; but I hope this apprehension will soon be removed— The very triumphs of the Russians will insensibly moderate their resentments— The dismissal of all the French actors and actresses, of both the Theatres at St: Petersburg and Moscow, from the Emperor’s service is this day officially announced in the Gazette— The funds applied heretofore to the payment of their Salaries, are to be appropriated to assist the sufferers by the War.

5. Mr J. W. Smith and Mr Forrester called upon me this morning— The latter is going soon with Mr Andrew to England, on their way to America. I offered to procure for them a Courier’s Passport.— Miss Frederica Bode, dined and spent the Evening with Mrs Adams and Catherine— I played a game of Chess with her.— Received notice of a Te Deum at the Imperial Chapel to-morrow, for fresh Victories gained by Count Wittgenstein.— The weather has again become severely cold and Reaumur’s thermometer last Night was at -20.3 degrees. The effect of this and other circumstances upon my hand is such that I can scarcely discharge my indispensable duties in writing.

6. I finished reading in course this morning the French Bible with Ostervald’s reflections— And began the second time upon Luther’s German Bible. At the head of which there are some useful remarks upon the temper and disposition with which the Scriptures should be read—these I also perused. At noon I went with Mr Smith, and attended the Te Deum at the Imperial Chapel— I asked Count Romanzoff for an interview to have some Conversation, and he appointed to-morrow Evening at 7 O’Clock, at his own house upon the Quay. General Betancourt asked me if I had received the answer on the application from Mr Fulton— I told him I had; and from his mentioning it I concluded he had been consulted upon it— He said he had; and that he had almost drawn up the answer— I thanked him on Mr Fulton’s Account, and said I hoped when he should come the General would be pleased with his Invention— He said he was already acquainted with it, and knew Mr Fulton very well; and was his friend— I told him I was happy Mr Fulton had chanced to have so good a friend at Court.— The Te Deum was attended by all the Diplomatic Corps— There was no Court, although it was St: Catherine’s day— After returning home I read prayers, and Sterne’s Sermon 10. upon Job’s complaint of the shortness and miseries of human life.— Walked on the Quay—the weather severely cold— Mr Smith dined at Mr Krehmer’s. In the Evening I read Mayhew’s Sermons 4 and 5. on sober-mindedness; and having had a sleepless Night, the last I was much fatigued and retired very early to bed.

7. On returning this morning from my walk, I found a Note from Count Romanzoff, proposing a change of the time and place which he had fixed for seeing me; and asking me to call upon him between one and two O’Clock this afternoon at the Hotel of foreign Affairs; which I accordingly did. I told him that my motive for asking this Conversation with him was, that since I saw him last, I had received from my Government official notice of the Declaration of War by the United States against Great-Britain, together with a letter from the Secretary of State dated the first of July—that I had not received any instruction to make an official communication on the subject to this Government; but the Secretary of State had explicitly expressed the views of the American Government at that juncture, on several points, which I thought it important to communicate to him— The first was the desire of the United-States, that this War might be confined to them, and Great-Britain; that no other power might be involved in it— That the United States wished to preserve unimpaired their relations of Amity with all other powers, and that
this wish was declared in a particular manner with regard to Russia.— That the War between Russia and France, though it could not then be known in America, to have commenced was anticipated as inevitable, and was a subject of great regret to the American Government.— That the state of our Affairs with France was said to be in an unsettled Condition, and there was not much expectation of any speedy settlement of them satisfactory to us— But that whatever course they might take, the American Government did not contemplate any more intimate connection with France; nor was it aware of any occurrence whatsoever, which could induce them to enter into any such connection— This sentiment I said was expressed in terms as strong as language could employ, and the desire of the United-States to maintain in their full extent the friendly and commercial relations with Russia, was in terms of equal earnestness— The Count said he was obliged to me for the Communication, which he was sure would be peculiarly agreeable to the Emperor, before whom he should lay the substance of it— That the Emperor’s desire to maintain the friendly and commercial relations with the United-States were entirely reciprocal to those of the American Government; and it was the apprehension that they might be interrupted by the English, which had made him wish so sincerely the termination of this War— That we might be assured that no circumstance whatsoever could induce the Emperor to interrupt the friendly relations of Russia with the United States; even if he were prepared to enter into more intimate engagements than he is at present inclined to form with any power whatsoever— And with regard to the assurance that the intention of the American Government was not to form any more intimate connection with France, as it would afford particular gratification to the Emperor, he wished to ascertain precisely whether he had understood what I stated as having been expressed to me in the Communication from my Government.— He then repeated over in substance, and correctly, what I had said; and I assured him that he had perfectly understood me— He asked me whether I had any objection to his communicating to the British Ambassador Lord Cathcart this part of what I had said to him— I answered that far from having any objection, I thought it might do good, and could not believe it would produce any unfavourable effect— That in the discussion of our differences with Great-Britain previous to the War, the British Ministers had frequently believed or professed to believe that the American Government were partial in favour of France, and were actuated by a French influence in opposition to England— If they really entertained such a prejudice, this frank and explicit declaration of my Government’s intentions, after the declaration of War against them, and precisely at that time, must if they were capable of giving it a candid consideration, tend to remove a prejudice, and to produce a more pacific disposition— The Count replied that he did not mean to say he thought this the only obstacle to the restoration of a good understanding between the United-States, and England; but he thought it a great one, and that it would be a favourable Circumstance to have it removed— He then asked me whether I had any late Intelligence from America, indicating the determination of the American Government, after the revocation of the orders in Council was known— I said I had not; but that although I was satisfied if that Revocation had been known the Declaration of War would not have been made, yet War being once declared there were other points of collision upon which an accommodation became essential, for the restoration of Peace; and upon the chief of these; the impressment of Seamen from our merchant vessels, it appeared the British Government would listen to nothing— I then explained to the Count the Nature and character of this practice, as exercised by the British naval Officers—the impossibility that any Nation having a sense of independence, and of the protection due to its own citizens should submit to it—or endure it without indignation; and I told him that two several proposals had been made by our Government to the British for a suspension of hostilities— The orders in Council to stand revoked; and they stipulating to discontinue the practice of impressment from American Vessels; the United States prohibiting by Law the employment of British Subjects either in their public ships or in private Merchant service— He said he thought the latter part of the stipulation could not easily be carried into Execution— I told him I did not think it could meet with much difficulty; but that at any rate the American Government having made the proposal would have been responsible for its execution.— The British Ministers however had rejected it; and untill they should be willing to come to some accommodation upon this point I saw no prospect of a Peace— I was aware, and did not wish to disguise that there was an inherent difficulty, which made the British adverse to a compromise— The Count asked if they did not complain that they lost great numbers of their Seamen, by their becoming naturalized as Americans— I said it was not exactly that— There were very few British Sailors who ever were or could be naturalized as Americans; and I mentioned to him the Conditions of naturalization by our Laws, and the character of them, which makes it sure that few foreign seamen can avail themselves of them— But I said the American Sea-service, public and private was more attractive than the British.— For our common Seamen were better fed, better paid, and better treated than English
English seamen are wont to be in their own service— It was natural therefore for English Sailors, to prefer our service to their own, and to seize every opportunity they could of entering it— This the English Government consider and complain of as seduction, and they have no other remedy against it than that violent and tyrannical practice of their naval Officers of stealing men from our merchant-vessels. I did not know that it would be possible ever to come to a compromise with them upon it; but I hoped if we could not hit upon any expedient for arranging it, he, the Count would furnish us with one— He said “il faudra travailler à cela”—and concluded by promising to give the Emperor an account of this Conversation, after which he said he would see me again.— After leaving him I called upon Captain Guedes, whom I found recovering from his illness, and looking much better than when I saw him last— Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us— I received this morning an Official Note from Count Soltykoff, with two printed Copies of the Treaty with Spain (Mr Zea’s) The Count still calls himself a privy Counsellor, directing the Department of foreign Affairs.

8. Mr Montreal called upon me this morning— He told me there was a report circulating in the City that Bonaparte (he is now nothing more than plain Bonaparte) was killed— We afterwards in the course of the day heard the same report from two other quarter’s; and even that his body had been found after a battle; that a Courier brought the news last Night; and that the fortress guns were fired for it, in the Night— There is said to be a Bulletin on the other hand from Admiral Tchichagoff, admitting that Bonaparte with seventy thousand men had passed beyond him— The weather is now so cold that it makes me more idle even than usual— I teach Charles, morning and Evening— He has learnt the version of the twenty-third Psalm; and continues learning St: Quentin’s grammatical play— We closed this Evening with Cards.

9. The thermometer is again at 15 and 16 degrees below 0. but I walk before breakfast and before dinner— I this day was abroad both at the rising and setting of the Sun— Mr Harris, and Messrs: Lewis, Willing, Fisher, Redwood, Andrew, and Gair dined with us— Mr Dimond, and Mr Forrester were invited, but sent apologies.— The news of the Emperor Napoleon’s being killed is not authenticated—that of his having effected his escape becomes more credited, though if true his situation must still be extremely perilous and almost desperate. The disappointment here at the belief of his escape is very great, and has given rise to various rumours that one and even two of the Russian armies have been defeated; of which there is probably no foundation— Some of the Gentlemen passed the Evening with us; and we had Cards.

10. On returning this morning from my walk I received a Note from the Chancellor Count Romanzoff, requesting me to call upon him at 12 O’Clock, at Noon, which I did— He said he had sent for me to shew me the draught of a despatch to Count Lieven, the Russian Ambassador in England; which he had prepared to lay before the Emperor for his approbation; and as its object was to communicate to Count Lieven the substance of what I had said to him in our last Conversation, he wished me to peruse it, and to point out any inaccuracy or variation from what I had said, and that he would immediately correct it— I found there were several passages differing from the ideas I had intended to convey to him, which he immediately struck out of the draught inserting others in their stead exactly conformable to what I now repeated and explained as having said or intended to say before—the Count observing that he was desirous of not using one expression either stronger or weaker than I had meant to use— The first variance was that he had written Count Lieven that I had called upon him by order of my Government, to communicate to him the Declaration of War by the United-States against Great-Britain— I had on the contrary said to him, that my Government had not ordered me to make any Official Communication here of this Declaration; but that having just received it, together with a despatch from the Secretary of State indicating the views of my Government on this occasion, in relation to other powers, and particularly to Russia, I had felt a duty to communicate the substance of it to him.— The second difference was that in reporting what I had mentioned of the state of our affairs with France, he had used expressions of resentment and reproach; such as that France used us as ill as Great-Britain—that she gave us nothing but “de belles paroles,” which I told him might be very just inferences from the facts, and might even express my own sentiments, but which I had not intended to use because my object had been merely to state the purport of the despatch I had received, in which no such expression of asperity, no sentiment even of irritation was to be found— It simply said that the principal subjects in discussion with France remained unsettled, and that there was little reason to expect a settlement of them satisfactory to us. On the third point I observed that the Count’s expressions were not so strong as those I had repeated from the Secretary of States letter— He had accurately noted the determination of the American Government, not to enter into more intimate connections with France, even if a satisfactory adjustment of those differences should be obtained; but he had omitted the additional assurance that they did not foresee any Event whatever, that could produce such a result. The Count immediately struck out every one of the passages which I noticed, as inaccurate, and inserted others in their stead exactly conformable to my present repetition and explanation of what I had said to him in our last
Conversation— I then told him that in consenting to the making of this Communication, to the British Government I was aware that it might possibly produce an effect different from that which he intended, and which I desired— That supposing the British Ministers should be actuated by dispositions, which might without any breach of candour be imputed to them, the certainty that the American Government would in no Event seek or accept a community of Cause with their most dreaded enemy, might render them more careless or indifferent to a pacification with us, as leading them to think less formidably of our hostility— That I believed however, the operation of this intelligence upon their minds, would be of an opposite kind—that its tendency would be to promote the Spirit of conciliation, and that I was in this respect happy to have the concurrence of his judgment— The Count said there was a possibility that the effect might be contrary to his wishes and intentions; but he trusted it would not— That his instruction to Count Lieven was to inform Lord Castlereagh of this Conversation with me, with the purpose of removing the prejudices entertained by the British Government; and of promoting the peace which he, Count Lieven knew the Emperor had much at heart; as believing it most for the interest of both powers, as well as of his own Empire— That he had not told Count Lieven that he was authorized by me to repeat this Conversation, but appeared to relate it altogether without my privity— That as the Affairs of the British in Spain were now not so prosperous as they had lately been, they would probably be under the necessity of making further efforts there, and might therefore be more disposed to accommodation in another quarter— He was quite anxious he said to hear from England— He had no accounts from thence later than 3 November, and now the only course of information even with regard to the internal state of France, was through England— I asked him if there was no communication through Sweden and Denmark— He said there was but very precarious and dilatory, for even before the war between Russia and France, the usual course of the Post between Paris and Copenhagen was through Moscow. I spoke to the Count of the answer the English Government had given to the Emperor’s proposed Mediation— He said they had neither accepted nor rejected it; but had hinted that it would not be acceptable in America—that they thought the time was not yet come— But it appeared they had sent out Admiral Warren, with powers to negotiate—did I know what the result had been of this?— I said I did not; but I augured very little from this mode of Negotiation— Admiral Warren had been known here, in a mere diplomatic capacity, and I had heard his personal character spoken of as amiable and conciliatory— But there he went also as commander in chief of a hostile squadron of ships, a character in itself far from portending conciliation— If we were vanquished indeed, an Admiral might signify to us the terms to which we must subscribe as well as any other; but untill then it was no good aspect for judging favourably of the proposals; to be offered from an Admiral making his first appearance in hostile array, with ships of the line and frigates— The Count replied that was true; but that to the amiable and conciliatory disposition of Sir John Borlase Warren he could bear ample and willing testimony— He was as free from pride, and from prejudices both personal and National as any Englishman he had ever known. At an early period of his Embassy, here, he, Count Romanzoff had told him that the commercial relations between Russia and England might be continued on a foundation of mutual advantage to both Nations; but not upon the basis of former times—not by viewing things under the varnish of the English factory— Not on the scale of maintaining here a dominion something like that they had in India— Supposing the Russian Commerce upon the Black Sea, were to become important? was the English factory to say that there must be none but at Petersburg?— It could not be endured— It was absolutely necessary to remember that times and things had changed— Sir John did not say any thing in answer to this at the time; but afterwards when he was going away, he told the Count that he had remembered that conversation, and was fully satisfied of the correctness of his opinion.— From the general tenor of the Count’s remarks I conjecture that he does not now very cordially harmonize with the English Ambassador, or fall into the present commercial or political views of the English Government— He said that he was happy to find that the British Ministers did full Justice to the Sentiments of the Emperor Alexander— More Justice indeed said he to the Emperor, than they do to his Chancellor— He told me that Mr Zea had lately sent him a despatch of an old date, from Mr Daschkoff, and asked me whether I knew how it came to Mr Zea’s hands— I suppose Mr Daschkoff sent it through the Spanish Minister by a Cartel-ship to England, from whence it was transmitted to Mr Zea, by a Courier.— After returning from Count Romanzoff’s I took a ride with Catherine and Charles— The cold continues inflexibly severe; and this Evening had penetrated into my Cabinet so that I could neither write nor read.— Abed before 8.

11. I had this day the fire kindled a second time in my Cabinet, which I had not needed through the whole of last Winter— My external thermometer, Reaumur’s, was at 15 degrees below 0. That of the Academy’s Register was at -20:3 Mine is placed in a Southern exposure, sheltered by the buildings in the yard— In cold weather it always shews from 3 to 6 degrees less of intenseness
than the Academy’s Register, and the thermometers on the Quay.— Mr Smith dined abroad, at Mr Lewis’s— I employed part of the Evening with Charles, and the rest at Ombre with the Ladies— Wrote to the Secretary of State; and a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr Andrew.

12. I had another entirely sleepless Night; of which I know no other cause than the severity of the Cold, which shakes my nervous system very roughly— I brave it more than some of my friends think wise, and have constantly taken my usual walk of nearly six miles, before breakfast— The weather as in all the coldest weather here, is clear; and as I rise before full day-light, I have got so much into the habit of walking immediately afterwards, that I find it irksome to stay within doors— Catherine Johnson was also unwell in the Night, and has been all this day confined to her bed— Charles has learnt Addison’s versions of the 19th: and 23d: Psalms— The first of them I think the best.— The second of J. B. Rousseau’s sacred Odes is a paraphrase of the same 19th: Psalm; or rather of the first part of it.— The French and English Poetry are beautiful; but there is a sublime simplicity in the original Psalm itself, more energetic than any thing in either of the imitations— Addison says that there is no real voice or sound in the firmament, and stars— I am not sure that the Psalm says so— Plato’s idea, of the music of the Spheres does not appear to have struck the Psalmist— But the Psalmists idea that they declare the glory and handy-work of God, was above the reach of Plato— Shakespear’s idea that they sing choiring to the young-eyed Cherubims is almost inspiration.— Addison’s Astronomy is adapted perhaps to the age when the Psalm was composed, and may pass for poetical Astronomy in any age; but the Psalm does not say that the stars and planets move round the Earth. In the 23d: Psalm, Addison’s introduction of the Crook displeases me—fainting in the sultry glebe, is aukwardly expressed; and faint will not rhyme with pant either to the ear or to the eye— In both the versions the thoughts are weakened by expansion and by repetition— Yet the twenty-third Psalm in Addison’s poetry is delightful by its rural imagery, and the 19th: is elevating by its grandeur

13. Catherine Johnson is still confined to her chamber, and almost entirely to her bed— The weather moderates occasionally three or four degrees, and as I have sometimes before observed in the severest weather here it moderates in the Night, and becomes colder after Sunrise— The Night produces a westerly wind, and cloudy sky, and the thermometer rises— The Sun dispels the clouds, and it sinks.— I read prayers for the third Sunday in Advent and Sterne’s Sermon 11. On Evil Speaking— Sterne’s own moral character was so equivocal to say the least, and from the allusions to it in his writings was so indiscreet withal, that he must have had his share of evil-speaking, which was not in his case, all slander— There is something in this Discourse that indicates particular references to himself and his own history, and his suggestion that St: James’s strong reprobation of Calumny might have been stimulated by his having been himself the object of it, leads naturally to the supposition that he conceived the idea by comparing his own case with the strong censures of the Saint.— There are passages in the Sermon keenly satirical; but not much levity— I also read Mayhew’s Sermons 6 and 7 on sober-mindedness— They conclude the first volume— It seems to be a course of ethics for young men; all derived from the exhortation to young men to be sober minded.— Mr Smith dined abroad.

14 I had a morning visit from Mr Raimbert— His situation is still precarious and full of anxiety— I received a note from Count Romanzoff requesting me to delay for one day the departure of Mr Andrew, that he might have time to prepare his dispatches for America. I employed the day in settling my Monthly Accounts.

15. My thermometer this morning was at 16 degrees below 0. The Academy Register was at -19:6 It moderated in the course of the day— I called upon Count Löwenhielm, and asked him for a Courier’s Passport for Mr Andrew; which he promised me— I had a various conversation with him, on the politics of the day; the triumphant career of the Russians, and the continual and still aggravated disasters of the French army—on the future prospects of Europe—on the Swedish and American Constitutions; and on the probable Restoration of the House of Bourbon in France.— The Count is highly gratified by the present course of Events, to which the policy adopted by Sweden has no doubt eminently contributed. Mr Andrew and Mr Plummer called upon me in the Evening, and Miss Bode paid a visit to Catherine Johnson, who is still confined to her chamber.— I read a few pages in Durand’s translation of Cicero’s Academics.

16. Received this morning from Count Romanzoff, the Courier’s Passport for Mr Andrew, and two packets for Mr: Daschkoff; to send by him— Mr Brandel also called upon me, and brought me a Passport for him from Count Löwenhielm— He told me that the Count’s brother, had arrived last Night from Stockholm upon a special mission; and had brought papers from England to 20 November— There were none before later than 3 Novr.— Dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a company of about 30 persons— It was a dinner to the new Spanish Minister the Chevalier Bardaxi y Azara, to whom Mr Zea introduced me— The two Count Löwenhielm’s were likewise there; and the Minister introduced me to his brother; he neither resembles him nor the old Count, the father with whom I was acquainted at the Hague— The day was again rendered festive by joyful tidings from the armies— The retaking of Willna by the Russians was the pleasant intelligence of this day. Count Romanzoff told me he had seen the English papers to the 20. Novr: and that the French had retaken Madrid— Lord Cathcart was not at the dinner— He was confined at home with the gout— His two sons were there— The Count received while at table a message from the Emperor,
requiring his attendance at half past six this Evening; which of course abridged a little the hour after dinner, of the company. I sat between Count Soltykoff and Baron Blome at dinner— After returning home I read a few pages of the Academics— Dr Galloway was here, to see Catherine Johnson, who this day first left her chamber since her illness.

17. Received a Notification for a Te Deum to morrow, for the retaking of Wilna— It being also the Russian festival of St: Nicolas; and the name day of one of the young Grand Dukes— I have continued walking in the morning untill this day, but I find myself again with one of those Colds which have proved so troublesome to me in this Country. the severe weather continues; my thermometer was this Evening again down at 15 below 0. the Academy’s Register at -21:3. I attended this day at a sale of books in the Perspective.— In the Evening we had Cards— Finished preparing my letters to be sent by Mr Andrew— I saw Mr Harris at the auction and mentioned to him the Te Deum to be performed to morrow.

18. Mr Montreal called upon me this morning, but finding me dressed to go out, made a short visit. Mr Andrew likewise came with Mr: Plummer I gave him my despatches and letters, together with Count Romanzoff’s two Packets for Mr Daschkoff— About one O’Clock afternoon I went with Mr Smith and attended the Te Deum— Lord Cathcart, the new Spanish Minister, and both the Counts Löwenhielm were there— After returning home, I took my ordinary daily walk; but that of the morning I was obliged to omit; the cold having affected my feet in such a degree as to make me lame— It had the same effect last Winter— I passed the Evening at home; read part of the Academics and a few pages of Dr Gisborne’s Duties of Men— But I was unwell; and the long continuance of the severe cold makes it impossible to be comfortable any where— This series of weather commenced precisely with the new Moon; which is this day Full— There has been no such a rigorous and constant succession of cold for so long a term without interruption since we have been here before— It affects my health; and I am alike unsuccessful whether I attempt to brave it, or to escape from it.

19. The Emperor Alexander left this City early this morning to go to the army. There have been for some days rumours of his departure, but they were so much contradicted that it was finally quite unexpected— I rose between 5 and 6 this morning; but was so lame that I could not walk before breakfast. Attended the auction of Books, where I only consumed two hours of the day— Afterwards I rode in the Carriage with Charles.— In the Evening I was quite unwell.— Mrs Adams was very ill; and Catherine has not recovered entirely from her illness— The rigour and continuance of the cold severely shakes the Constitutions of Strangers, accustomed to milder climates; and particularly affects us all— I joined in Charles’s sports this morning to give him exercise, and in the Evening for his instruction.

20. Having procured an additional protection for my feet from the cold, I walked again this morning with the Thermometer at -20:9 degrees. I took also a second walk before dinner— Read prayers for the fourth Sunday in Advent, and Sterne’s Sermon 12. on the forgiveness of injuries, illustrated by the history of Joseph and his brethren— He has hardly made so much of this subject as it deserved— The Story itself is so affecting that Sterne’s powers of Pathos should have exhibited it to more advantage— I likewise read Mayhew’s Sermons 8 & 9 the first two of the second Volume, upon sober-mindedness— Dr Mayhew was a clergyman of Boston with whom my Parents were intimately acquainted; and the father of Mrs Wainwright— He was an eminent man in his life-time; but of these Sermons I never saw any other copy than my own; and I never heard them mentioned in America— As they were printed in London, I have always supposed that they were the work of some English clergyman of the same name— But upon perusing them I find so many internal marks of the author’s character as I have always heard it spoken of, and so many sentiments peculiar to the region where the Doctor lived and died, that I have no doubt that they were written by him— They are very good discourses; in a plain, unornamented style, abounding with strong sense, and virtuous principle— Earnest, even to harshness in their manner; interspersed with occasional strokes of severe Satire; too blunt for wit; and too serious for sarcasm— The popular right of resistance against tyranny is introduced and asserted with a spirit which I consider as one of the proofs of the place where the sermons were delivered— The author is more bitter in his censures upon the quakers, and other fanatical sectaries, than upon the Romish Church. There is a critical note on a passage from St: Paul, which refers to the idiom of the Greek language; and there are several apt quotations from Horace— I perceive no other very strong traces of learning— Mrs Adams continued quite ill the whole day— Charles was also unwell.— I spent the Evening entirely with him, in reading and studying St: Quentin’s Lessons of Grammar— This Evening there was at length an appearance of abatement in the rigour of the Cold— My thermometer rose to -9 degrees— This is the seventeenth day that the cold has continued in succession.

21. I found this morning that six 25 Ruble bills had been stolen from the draw of my table where I keep my money. It has happened to me several times before, and I have within the last six Months lost in this manner at least 1500 Rubles— My chamber door and my table draw must both have been opened with false keys— I have two servants in the house whom I know to be thieves, but whom I have not dismissed from despair of procuring others more honest. I doubt whether any possible vigilance can guard against these depredations— Mine at least is insufficient.— I attended the Auction, and purchased a few books— Mrs Adams was very ill all day, and Catherine Johnson extremely ill this Evening. Dr: Galloway was twice here— Charles too is unwell— The Cold weather has at length abated, and this morning we had snow. In the Evening however it grew cold again, and the thermometer was at -10— I pass’d as much of the Evening as I could with Charles.

22 I attended at the Auction, where various articles of furniture, and of curiosity were this day sold; but no books— There were a variety of Mathematical instruments, the uses of which I did not sufficiently understand— I read a few pages in the second Volume of Gisborne’s Duties of Men, but was engaged almost the whole Evening with Charles. Mrs Adams and Catherine were both much better than yesterday; but Catherine is confined to her chamber— We have at length reached the Winter Solstice, and the days are at their shortest period; only 5 1/2 hours in the twenty-four. I make but a very indifferent use, even of them.— Charles took his first lesson of writing from a Master.

23. Resumed my long early morning walk, and took a second before dinner— I was amusing Charles with one of St: Quentin’s grammatical lessons, and the descriptive Counters, when Mr Harris came in and passed the remainder of the Evening with us. Catherine Johnson still keeps her chamber, and Charles has a cough, which always alarms me— I found no time for reading, and scarcely any for writing.

24. The Emperor Alexander’s birth day, which for the first time since I have been here, passed over without any celebration; and almost without notice— There was a petty illumination of the Streets for about two hours in the Evening; and nothing more— The Country has suffered so much by the last Summer’s invasion, and there have perished such great multitudes of the people and armies, while other multitudes still greater are reduced to ruin and beggary, that the Emperor himself has determined there should be no expensive festivities this winter at his Court; and he particularly forbade the customary celebration of his birth-day.— After passing two hours this Evening with Charles at the grammatical diversion, and reading about two more in Dr Gisborne’s Duties of Men, I was playing at Ombre with the Ladies when I received a Note from Mr Harris, with a London Gazette Extraordinary of 27. November, containing the official account (British) of the total defeat of the second American attempt to invade Upper Canada, and the surrender of General Wadsworth and 900 men.— The symptoms disclosed by these repeated shameful terminations, of impotent assaults, are distressing to the feelings of one who loves his Country. The reliance of man in all cases can only be upon Heaven— God grant, that these disasters instead of sinking, may rouse the Spirit of the Nation, and that they may learn, though from adversity, the skill and discipline which will be the pledges of their future prosperity!—

25. Christmas day, by the ordinary European Calendar— I had morning visits from Mr Harris, and Captain Guedes— I attended the auction about half an hour; but found them disposing of books of no value to me— I dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a Company of about sixty persons; the Corps Diplomatique, and the principal Ministers of the Country. I was seated at table between Count Maistre and the Duke de Polignac, with both of whom I had much Conversation— The news, was the evacuation of Courland by the French, and the taking of 3000 Prussians, prisoners by the Marquis de Paulucci the Governor of Riga— This was so small an affair amidst the multitude of great and brilliant successes of the Russian arms, that it was spoken of rather contemptuously— Count Romanzoff, laughing heartily, and apologizing to me for laying aside the reserve of the Chancellor, told me that the boys in the Streets who sold the Bulletins, when they followed persons and found them slow to take their goods, would urge them by saying Oh! take it! take it!— It is not from Paulucci but from Wittgenstein.— The new comer Count Löwenhielm appeared to be in a sort of extasy after dinner, at the band of music; particularly the horns, in the chamber adjoining the dining Hall— Admiral Bentinck complained that they smelt too strong of human nature— The Admiral told me that Napoleon had confiscated in Holland property belonging to him, worth an hundred thousand pounds Sterling.— On returning home I found Miss F. Bode, who had dined with the Ladies— She soon left us to go to a Concert at Lord Cathcart’s. We finished the Evening with Cards.

26. The last of the shortest days at the solstice— From this day they begin to lengthen— I was at the auction and made some purchases, but as often happens, not of the articles for which I went. Walk afterwards— In the Evening I went with Mrs Adams, Charles and Mr Smith to the German theatre— Catherine was not sufficiently recovered to go out— The performance was Das Neue Sonntags Kind, a ridiculous Opera with very good music; and a Ballet called the goldene hochzeit.

27. I read prayers for the Sunday after Christmas, and Sterne’s Sermon 13. on the duty of setting bounds to our desires. The Story of Elisha and the Shunemite— Like many others of these discourses it finishes abruptly. He usually draws a large outline, and often fills up only a part of it— He says they were all hastily composed, and they strongly bear the marks of it— But they have always a good practical moral, and they have the art of fastening upon the attention of the reader beyond any sermons that I ever read— They are of very different lengths, but all appear to be short— This is one of the reasons why the end always comes upon one unawares— I also read Mayhew’s 10th: Sermon upon sober-mindedness; with which the hortatory part of the work commences. Mr Smith dined at Mr Krehmer’s— I have for some days omitted my early morning walk— I still have a Cold hanging upon me; but Charles’s has become quite severe— I gave up the whole Evening to him—

28. Walked again this morning before Breakfast— And as the Evening twilight came on; that is, about 3. O’Clock in the afternoon I went to the Bookseller Höwert’s to look at some German school-books; for the purpose of teaching Charles to read German— I did not however find any to my satisfaction; and I believe I shall postpone at least for some months longer the commencement of his German lessons. He is now occupied as large a portion of his time, and with as great a variety of studies, as I think at his age can be pursued to advantage— His reading both in French and English is yet so imperfect that I cannot venture to intermit his daily exercise in each of them. His English Spelling-Book, occasionally employs him another hour, under his mother’s tuition— He is not yet satiated with the grammatical amusement of St: Quentin’s descriptive Counters and Cards of exercises at which we had this Evening two hours of close study.— I am endeavouring to fix his attention imperceptibly to himself upon numbers; preparatory to the first lessons of arithmetic.— His writing and Russian master now attends him twice a week, and he daily scrawls cyphered figures upon his Slate— On the whole, without being subjected to the regularity of school-hours (which I regret) he has not less than six hours of assiduous instruction every day— May the blessing of God rest upon it, for [“]Except the Lord build the house: their labour is but lost that build it. Except the Lord keep the City, the watchman waketh but in vain!”— I employed also about two hours of this day in writing; my neglect of which is a continual occasion of self-reproach; of no use, because not followed by amendment— We closed the Evening with Cards.

29. Charles has a cold, cough, and bleeding at the nose, precisely like that which alarmed us so much towards the close of the last Winter— This day Dr Galloway came and prescribed for him— I attended at the auction and purchased a few Books— Heard there of the death of Prince George of Oldenburg the Grand Duchess Catherine’s husband— The theatres were shut upon this occasion— Charles this day finished reading the Psalter, in the Evening he made cyphers upon his slate; read one of Bouilly’s tales to his daughter, and played with the descriptive Counter’s. He has a thirst for learning, beyond his years, and at the same time a singular aversion at being taught. He chuses to learn every thing in his own way. With the Ladies and Mr Smith we finished the Evening by a rubber of whist.

30. Received notice from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin, of a Court Mourning, to commence this day for Prince George of Holstein-Oldenburg— Its duration and divisions into full and half-mourning, are to be notified hereafter— Probably they must be fixed by the orders of the Emperor.— The Messenger who brought me the notification also informed me that the Master of the Ceremonies the Commandeur de Maisonneuve died this morning at 3 O’Clock, of an Apoplectic stroke— He had been complaining nearly these two years; but attended at the last Te Deum— The Messenger told me he had been two or three days; but was seized with the Apoplexy about nine O’Clock last Evening— My first acquaintance with Mr de Maisonneuve at Berlin; where I found him in 1797. Minister, from the Order of Malta— When the Emperor Paul assumed the character of Grand-Master of that order; he sent to Berlin for Mr Maisonneuve; who has been ever since then here— When the present Emperor reformed the Maltese Establishment, he gave the Commandeur the Office of Master of the Ceremonies— He was a man of mild temper and amiable manners; extremely well-bred; well versed in French and Italian Literature, and a lover and Connoisseur of the Fine Arts— His Office here was not at-all suited to his disposition, though he understood thoroughly the Science of courtly Etiquette. An indolent and luxurious life, which he had probably long led, brought on him their ordinary consequences; at first nervous and hypocondriac disorders; which have now thus terminated. He was not much turned of 50. and originally of a strong and healthy Constitution— I had this day only one walk; and that before dinner— Began reading the New Testament with Charles— But as his indisposition continues, with symptoms of increasing severity, and as he appeared disinclined to his usual Evening sport and employment, I
I left him to pursue his own taste, and finished reading Dr: Gisborne’s Work on the Duties of Men— This author without having the acuteness of intellect which distinguishes Dr Paley, has more of that clear plain common sense which constitutes a sound judgment. I think his principles of Morality preferable to those of Paley; but his works are far from being so popular as Paley’s. In this work his plan is more specific and particular than comports with a general Treatise of Moral Philosophy— It applies to men, in the higher and middle classes of Society in Great-Britain— The Sovereign—the Peerage—Parliament—The Clergy—the Bar—the Faculty—Persons engaged in trade and business; and finally Private Gentlemen—concluding with a few Reflections addressed to infidels. The parts of the Book relating to Magistrates—to members of the Legislature—to Professional men; and to private Gentlemen, are in a great measure applicable to Americans as well as to Englishmen— I have found in them many remarks which I ought to turn to my own improvement.— We closed the Evening again at Whist.

31. Rose at five O’Clock; and after my regular morning reading and writing, and commencing a letter to my Mother, I took my five Miles Walk, with my Thermometer at 15 degrees below 0 and the Academy’s Register at -I received an invitation to attend the funeral Ceremony for Mr Maisonneuve, at the Maltese Chapel to-morrow morning at ten O’Clock— Went to the Auction and continued my purchases— Charles continues so unwell that he was this day confined to the warm chambers— This Evening he appeared better— I played with him at his Counters and his nine-pins; and released him from all the studies that are irksome to him— We spent a couple of hours of the Evening at Cards.

Day. I have risen every morning this month, before day light— Usually between 6 and 7— The state of Health in my family has effectually prevented me from establishing and observing the rule which I should wish to follow, of rising every morning at five— The severity of the Season presents another obstacle; for my chamber is too cold in the morning, for writing or reading with comfort— This difficulty however would not be insuperable without the other— I begin the day by reading five Chapters in the Bible— Write the Journal of the preceding day— Each of which occupations employs from half an hour to an hour— Walk five or six Miles— This however I sometimes omit— Breakfast about ten— Hear Charles read English, and learn to recite—and sometimes teach him to write cyphers upon his slate— This engages two full hours— Read or write, or arrange household concerns untill dark; which is now before 3 in the afternoon— Walk another hour— Return and read or write untill 5. dine— From 6 to 9. I bestow again upon Charles;—and chiefly to his amusement— Nine is the hour of the Ladies for tea— After which we sometimes pass an hour or two at Cards, and sometimes I retire immediately to bed— I scarcely ever visit or dine abroad; and am very seldom interrupted by visitors or have Company at home.

I offer to a merciful God at the close of this year, my humble tribute of Gratitude, for the blessings with which he has in the course of it favoured me, and those who are dear to me— And I pray for a continuance of his Goodness— Above all I pray that He who worketh in us both to will and to do, may grant to me and mine that temper of Heart and that firmness of soul, which are best adapted duly to receive all His dispensations whether joyous or afflictive— It has pleased him in the course of this year to lay his chastening hand upon me, and to try me with bitter sorrow. My endeavours to quell the rebellion of the Heart, have been sincere; and have been assisted with the blessing from above— As I advance in life; its evils multiply. the instances of mortality become more frequent, and approach nearer to myself— The greater is the need of fortitude to encounter the woes that flesh is heir to, and of religion to support pains, for which there is no other remedy— Religious Sentiments become from day to day more constantly habitual to my mind— They are perhaps too often seen in this Journal— God alone can make even Religion a Virtue; and to him I look for aid that mine may degenerate into no vicious excess. For the future time may the favour of God, which passeth all Understanding rest upon my Parents, my Wife and all my Children; my kindred, friends and Country; nor at this moment can I forbear to include in my petitions the welfare of all Human Kind.— For myself, may the divine Energies be granted to perform fully all my duties to God, to my fellow mortals in all the relations of life, and to my own Soul—
